title: 104_s1842
content:
The "Workers' Pension Protection Act of 1996" includes amendments to pension plan funding requirements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, specifically addressing the treatment of multiemployer plans. The "Workers' Pension Protection Act of 1996" imposes limitations on benefit increases for underfunded and well-funded multiemployer plans to ensure financial stability. Plans with a funded current liability percentage of 95% or less cannot increase benefits, while plans with 95% or more funding must not increase benefits that would lower the funded percentage below 90%. The "Workers' Pension Protection Act of 1996" restricts benefit increases for certain plans until they reach a funded current liability percentage of 95% or more. The interest rate used for determining current liabilities is specified, ensuring financial stability for multiemployer plans. The "Workers' Pension Protection Act of 1996" limits benefit increases for certain plans until they reach a funded current liability percentage of 95% or more. The specified percentage for the weighted average is determined for this purpose. The "Workers' Pension Protection Act of 1996" limits benefit increases for certain plans until they reach a funded current liability percentage of 95% or more. The specified percentage for the weighted average is determined for this purpose. In the case of plan years beginning in calendar years 1996 to 2000, the specified percentages are 109, 108, 107, 106, and 105 respectively. The mortality table used for determining current liability in earlier plan years is prescribed by the Secretary of Labor. The prevailing standard table used by the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service to determine reserves for group annuity contracts issued on January 1, 1993, will be replaced by mortality tables prescribed by the Secretary of Labor for plan years starting after December 31, 1999. Benefits for a plan described in section 3(37) include all benefits to participants and their beneficiaries. The term 'current liability' for a plan described in section 3(37) means all liabilities to participants and their beneficiaries under the plan. The 'unfunded current liability' is the excess of the current liability over the value of plan assets, reduced by any credit balance in the funding standard account. The Secretary of Labor may provide for such reduction for purposes of any other provision referencing this subsection. The funded current liability percentage is defined as the percentage of the amount determined under paragraph (3)(B) to the current liability under the plan for a plan described in section 3(37). SEC. 102 amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to allow for a reduction in accrued benefits resulting from an increase in benefits prohibited by section 308. SEC. 103 requires notice to participants and others of a multiemployer plan's funding status. SEC. 103 amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to require trustees of multiemployer plans to provide annual notice to participants, beneficiaries, and contributing employers about the plan's funding status. SEC. 104 states that these amendments apply to plans starting after December 31, 1996. TITLE II--ACTUARIAL ASSUMPTIONS

SEC. 201. INTEREST RATE AND MORTALITY ASSUMPTIONS USED.

Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to specify the interest rate and mortality assumptions used for determining an employer's withdrawal liability. Effective for plan years beginning after December 31, 1996. The amendments made by Title III apply to plans starting after December 31, 1996. It amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to include new enforcement requirements for employers contributing to multiemployer plans. SEC. 302 amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to allow attorney's fees in actions by employers. SEC. 303 amends the Act regarding civil actions by corporations. SEC. 304 states that these amendments apply to plans starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 401 eliminates special vesting rule for multiemployer plans. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to remove subparagraph (C) and modify the effective date for plan years beginning after December 31, 1996, or January 1, 1999. These amendments do not apply to individuals without certain qualifications. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to exclude individuals with less than one hour of service under the plan after the specified date.
